prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Location of evidence

para.paratext: The Panel has frequently considered the location of documents and witnesses in selecting a transferee district. If witnesses and documents that are inevitably going to be involved in pretrial proceedings are located within a single district, that district is a strong candidate for transferee district.[1] In addition to documentary evidence, location of physical evidence may affect the Panel's decision. In some cases, the physical evidence is bulky and unmovable, such as the wreckage from a commercial airliner crash. The location of government agencies having involvement in the litigation may also be considered by the Panel.[2] This factor is not, however, a controlling factor.[3]

It is important not to view this factor as being as compelling as it once was. Before the advent of online document depositories and the potential availability of all the documents in a case on a single CD-ROM or web-accessible depository, the location of documents was a very important factor. Today, it is an unusual case where the simple location of documents is important to the Panel. Location of evidence is still relevant, but it is diminished in importance, especially as to documentary evidence.

The Panel has considered the location of evidence that has been produced for a grand jury as a factor favoring selection of the district in which the grand jury was convened.[4] In certain respects this factor is similar in this context to the factor favoring a district that would permit coordination between the transferred cases and other federal court litigation.[5] The Panel has inferred from the location of an important defendant that documents are located there and discovery will occur there.[6]

Even if the evidence is not located within a potential transferee district, proximity to the district may favor selection of a particular district. For example, if many documents and witnesses are located in Los Angeles, within the Central District of California, their location may be a factor favoring the selection of the Northern District of California (San Francisco) if other factors make the Southern District of New York and the Northern District of California the only seriously considered potential transferee districts.[7] In another case, the Panel transferred actions to the District of the District of Columbia in part because of the presence of a large number of documents in Virginia, adjacent to the District.[8] One reason that proximity to the transferee district may be sufficient is the subpoena power of the federal courts, and its reach up to 100 miles outside the district.[9]

The physical location of documents once appeared to be most important to the Panel. This is especially true if the contemplated discovery will take place where the documents are located. In one case the Panel transferred cases to the Eastern District of Pennsylvania because the documents relevant to the cases were housed there despite the fact they were under the legal control of the bankruptcy court in New York.[10] The location of documentary evidence may be affected by the litigation. The Panel has considered the location of a document depository created for the litigation,[11] although it is unlikely this factor would have any weight today, given the availability and widespread use of online document depositories.

This factor has been applied by the Panel through discussion of the location of the parties' offices. The Panel may infer from the location of the offices where evidence is likely to be located.[12] The mere location of a party with a central role in the cases, typically the “target” defendant, may be enough to meet this criterion, without express attention to whether evidence is likely to be there.[13] A common location of multiple defendants may be an even stronger factor in selecting the transferee district.[14] Although often expressed in terms of the location of a party's “headquarters,”[15] the presence of operational offices, as opposed to executive offices, may be sufficient and significant to the Panel.[16] Similarly, the location of government offices or agencies may be important to the Panel.[17] The Panel in one case took a Solomonic approach, chosing a district “midway between the defendants' relevant headquarters.”[18] A party's former headquarters may be significant.[19] The location of an important non-party may be important in a particular case. In one docket the Panel found the location of a trade association that would likely be the subject of discovery to be relevant to selection of the transferee court.[20] Similarly, in cases relating to trading on stock or commodity exchanges, even if the exchange is not a party, the location of the exchange may be a compelling destination for the litigation.[21]

The location of evidence, and particularly witnesses, has probably become less important as the Panel realizes that discovery can effectively be conducted anywhere in the country regardless of the venue of the action. Additionally, this concern may be a lingering preference in the pre-Lexecon era, when selection of the transferee district was often effectively the selection of the place of trial.[22] Because cases are expected to be tried where filed, if trial is needed, location of evidence has less bearing on the forum-selection issue for pretrial matters.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Municipal Mortg. & Equity, LLC, Securities and Derivative Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Hannaford Bros. Co. Customer Data Sec. Breach Litigation, 559 F. Supp. 2d 1405 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Wells Fargo Mortg. Lending Practices Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Family Dollar Stores, Inc., Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Medtronic, Inc., Sprint Fidelis Leads Products Liability Litigation, 536 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Mercedes-Benz Tele Aid Contract Litigation, 537 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Washington Mut., Inc., Securities, Derivative & ERISA Litigation, 536 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Graphics Processing Units Antitrust Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (2 defendants' principal place of business in transferee district).

See, e.g., In re Atlas Roofing Corp. Chalet Shingle Products Liability Litigation, 988 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (sales office of defendant and several homes at issue in litigation located in district); In re Kaplan Higher Educ. Corp. Qui Tam Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1323 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (defendant has “a headquarters” in district); In re Static Random Access Memory (SRAM) Antitrust Litigation, 473 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (many defendants “have presence” in transferee district); In re Bausch & Lomb Inc. Contact Lens Solution Products Liability Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1336 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (location of manufacturing facility); In re Canon U.S.A., Inc., Digital Cameras Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (location of principal place of business); In re Medtronic, Inc., Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 408 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (location of headquarters); In re Delphi Corp. Securities, Derivative and “ERISA” Litigation, 403 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (location of principal place of business); In re Guidant Corp. Implantable Defibrillators Products Liability Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (“key facilities” involved in development and manufacturing of devices located in transferee district); In re CP Ships Ltd. Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (major domestic office in transferee district).

In re Iraq and Afghanistan Detainees Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer to D.D.C. because nation's capital provides a particularly appropriate forum for actions against Secretary of Defense); In re Federal Nat. Mortg. Ass'n Securities Derivative & “ERISA” Litigation, 370 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer to D.D.C. because Fannie Mae located there).
In re Air Crash Near Medan, Indonesia, On September 5, 2005, 544 F. Supp. 2d 1379, 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2008).

In re Le-Nature's, Inc., Commercial Litigation, 609 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (location of defunct defendant's headquarters); In re Peregrine Systems, Inc., Securities Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (transfer in this case was also unopposed, which may have been the most compelling reason for selection).

In re Rail Freight Fuel Surcharge Antitrust Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2007). See also In re Google Android Consumer Privacy Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (in addition to Google headquarters, non-party application developers located in district).

In re: London Silver Fixing, Ltd., Antitrust Litigation, 52 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Commodity Exchange, Inc., Gold Futures and Options Trading Litigation, 38 F. Supp. 3d 1394 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: Aluminum Warehousing Antitrust Litigation, 988 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013) (exchange alleged to be central participant in alleged conspiracy); In re: North Sea Brent Crude Oil Futures Litigation, 978 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013); In re: Dairy Farmers of America, Inc., Cheese Antitrust Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2009).
See generally § 3:2.
